Posts.Content: Brilliant news about the biopsy and fingers crossed for your job.  Sending you best wishes for tomorrow, lets hope the side effects start to ease soon xxx
Posts.Title: Over Emotional....

Posts.Content: Hello Londonlass, you offload all you need, you just have to sit and have a good cry sometimes!!! I'm on Zoladex too due 2nd injection next week and like you I seem to find even trivial things make me want to cry.......Ikea adverts included.....at least we have this great community here to listen to us. Dreamthief is completely right, we are leaking oestrogen and it is giving us these low moods and wobbles. I saw my GP yesterday, she sat and listened to me and said this is all completely normal. I haven't had any balance issues, but have problems putting things in things.....i couldn't put a teabag in a mug, I knew it  had to go in the mug but kept dropping it on the unit, and my washing machine keeps having fabric softener drips down it where i try to pour....really strange.  I hope you start to feel a little better soon but you know where we all are if you need a moan! xx best wishes Nicola
Posts.Title: Over Emotional....

Posts.Content: Hello Londonlass I had my first Zoladex 2 weeks ago, low mood kicked in yesterday, and with exemestane added to the mix, my concentration is zilch at the minute. 'Zoning out' for me is forgetting what I was saying mid conversation......very frustrating and its only been two weeks....my onco is trying to keep this blessed disease out of my bones, so I'm having to grin and bear it. If any of the above doesn't make sense........hormones....little blighters. However, one thing is for sure.......you will never be alone on this forum!! Best wishes Nicola
Posts.Title: Hormone Therapies, Mood and Memory.....

Posts.Content: Hello Millie, I was the same as you, 1/3 nodes positive this did not show on scan prior to surgery. I had to decide between removal of nodes via surgery or radiotherapy to armpit and collarbone. I opted for the radiotherapy as I had healed nicely from the SNB surgery. I was very much steered towards radiotherapy by my oncologist who gave me the statistics surrounding surgery vs radiotherapy. I accepted the radiotherapy and now have 4 sessions left of 23. Phew! However, if you do opt for radiotherapy, please ask that they cover the whole armpit area, they have only covered half my armpit, the radiotherapy causes slight darkening of the skin and I can see only half my armpit has been 'zapped' which is slightly concerning. In hindsight, maybe I should have been more assertive during my onco appointment and pushed to have the nodes removed, and I shall be bringing my half zapped armpit issue up at my next appt. Sending you very best wishes and good luck with what you decide Nicola xx
Posts.Title: double rads?

Posts.Content: Thank you Helen, I will give them a call and yes, keeping positive and optimistic  x
Posts.Title: Absorption of hormone therapy following gall bladder removal

Posts.Content: Hello All, I am 1 year post diagnosis, and have just had 1 year mammogram and am awaiting results as found another lump in May. Surgeon thinks it is scar tissue  and also says I have lymphoedema in my affected breast and arm. There is currently a 5 week wait here in Cornwall for mammogram results.....yikes!!! My question is, in April this year I had to have my gall bladder removed and since then have been suffering with chronic diarrhoea as I am producing too much bile. GP is now looking into this as still getting a lot of pain and loosing weight. Could this diarrhoea be preventing my medications from being absorbed? Just a thought? Has anyone else experienced similar? Thank you Nicola
Posts.Title: Absorption of hormone therapy following gall bladder removal

Posts.Content: hello Bids24 I am having similar problems, I guess when they do the lymph nodes they mess with the nerves and it all gets inflamed. My GP has prescribed me low dose amytriptiline as this can help, along with the ibuprofen.  I am still having this pain, but it has eased as the swelling has gone down. Try to persevere with the arm exercises, my BCN particularly said the walking up the wall one is good, where you try to reach as far as comfortable with your arm against a wall. It helped for me and just gentle stretching throughout the day. I hope it eases for you soon  best wishes Nicola xx
Posts.Title: Nerve pain to elbow: advice welcome

Posts.Content: Bless you Bids24, it is horrible, it feels like a step back, but you will get there.  The Amytriptiline I have are 10mg you take 1 at night and they have sedative effect for a few nights but as you get used to them this eases. My GP said they take about 10 days to work, I have had them for 9 now and I can tell a difference. Pain is not completely gone, but is more manageable. I hope you feel better soon  Nicola x
Posts.Title: Nerve pain to elbow: advice welcome

Posts.Content: Hello everyone, Ist oncologist appt yesterday, WLE & SNB in July revealed unexpected positive lymph node(1/3). Hormones receptors positive but HER2 neg.  I half expected to be told chemo, but as only 5% benefit and my allergies to antibiotics high, it is too risky. As an alternative, I am being offered axillary clearance, radiotherapy to the breast and armpit, along with Zoladex (Goserelin), Aromasin (exemestane) and Zometa (Bone infusion).  The Zoladex will put me into menopause and sounds horrendous.....monthly injections into tummy followed by night sweat, hot flushes etc. The Aromasin will be added in once the oestrogen levels have dropped sufficiently, followed by the bone infusion in 6 months to stop osteoporosis from the Aromasin!!!! I can handle the surgery and probably the daily two hour round trip for radiotherapy for a month, but the hormone treatment is freaking me out. I feel I am a very young 50 yr old, I know the natural menopause is approaching, but that it what I want it to be....natural. The other thing is why give one pill...Aromasin...and then give another to counteract its effect....Zometa? The side effects of these drugs sound horrendous, and I know everyone is different and some people will not have anything, but I hate taking pills for anything because I can be sensitive.... I even reacted to the SNB dye!!  I am in such a quandary again, my washing machine head is back and I am back to the worries I had before surgery, spending most of yesterday afternoon in tears (weak I know). Can I be sure that surgery RT and Hormones are going to be enough to conquer this damn cancer???? Sorry for the long post Nicola x
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy & Hormone treatment positive lymph node

Posts.Content: Hello Mistymoley, Puzzler and Kacang, Thank you for your replies, although I still feel nervous about the hormones, you have all shed some light on the situation, and as always are completely right. I don't know what I would have done without this wonderful forum and website, we are so lucky to have Macmillan!!! Next trip to the oncologist is within a fortnight, and I now have some valid questions to ask her about the hormone therapy. Next decision is surgery to clear the axillary or radiotherapy to the area and the oncologist is bringing the radiologist with her for my next appointment. My thought is cut it out get rid, but I am going to listen to what the radiologist has to say first as I am still having probs with my underarm post op (swelling & slight cording - stretching all the time to alleviate!!!).  Thank you all again Nicola
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy & Hormone treatment positive lymph node

Posts.Content: It is a bit of a shock, and yes how rude.....I a thinking same as you, my appointment with oncologist is mid August so should know a bit more then. Best wishes for your treatment, and keep in touch xx Nicola
Posts.Title: Lymph Node positive what happens next??

Posts.Content: Hello Pepperabbit,  thank you for your reply, this is the thing with a positive lymph node, what if others are affected? How was the radiotherapy for you? This is the one that scares the life out of me, a family member had a really bad experience and I suffer from really sensitive skin. I know I have to have it and think personally I would prefer this to further surgery.....3 weeks post op and my armpit is like hello girl, its me all swollen and painful.....and why does it stick to the side of my boob, are they missing each other?? Lol.  I know it sounds strange, but I will be glad once the Onco appt is here, I like a plan, once you have a plan you can move another step forward!! Best wishes Nicola
Posts.Title: Lymph Node positive what happens next??

Posts.Content: Hello Lyndsey, Thank you for your reply, darn cancer, how dare it play with our lymph nodes. Personally, I am not keen on further surgery to the axilla, the recovery from the SLNB has been 'uncomfortable' to say the least. I am going to listen carefully to the oncologist, all my family are like, have everything (chemo), but I don't want to be over treated if not necessary. I think radiotherapy will probably be a way forward for me.  Very best wishes to you for your chemo, and keep in touch xx Nicola
Posts.Title: Lymph Node positive what happens next??

Posts.Content: Hello everyone, I am 3 weeks post op following wide local excision to remove IDC. Hormone receptors are good at ER8 and PR8 with HER2 neg. Been told I will need hormone treatment and bisothingys but unexpectedly (ultrasound did not show this) I have macrometastasis of 1 lymph node.  My brilliant consultant explained possible scenarios, axillary clearance, radiotherapy of axilla and breast plus the possibility of chemo, and I wondered if anyone else has had a similar experience? There was also mention of the POSNOC trial, has anyone enrolled for this?? Many thanks Nicola
Posts.Title: Lymph Node positive what happens next??
